Entry.1:
Sighted the Lizard Lighthouse about 8.30pm

Very rough
Entry.2:
Arrived in Plymouth at 4am this morning. Left the Borda at 2pm by the steamer (Sir Walter Raleigh) Left Plymouth 4-15pm by G.W.Rly. Stopped at Exeter for about 20 minutes (arr. there about 6pm) and were given tea and buns by the ladies of that city. Arr.Tidworth at 10pm then had a four mile march to Parkhouse Camp. Arr.Parkhouse about 12 midnight and

were kept standing in the cold for two hours, as the officials had nothing prepared for our coming and we had to be allotted to huts and issued with ets. Got into bed about 2am.

Melb.to Plymouth 11 weeks 4 days.

Parkhouse Camp

Parkhouse Camp

Allotted to our right huts 30 men in each

Tucker very good very short of bread

Parkhouse

 As there are no guns or horses in this camp, we only have foot drill and route marches
Entry.5:
LONDON

Disembarkation leave started at 6am. Left camp about 7.30 am marched to Amesbury arr. there 8.30am train to London changed trains at Salisbury. Arr London (Waterloo) 12 noon. Marched to Horseferry Rd. and paid up to the end of our leave then dismissed. Spent the day in London and caught the Flying Scotsman at 10pm from Kings Cross to Edinburgh. Rec.3 pounds 4 shillings at Horseferry Rd.
Entry.6: Arrived in Edinburgh about 8am. Met at the (Waverley) station by Mr and Mrs McLauchlan. Slept that night in Leith.
Entry.7: Caught the 8am tram from Waverley station for Glasgow. Met at Queen St station by Bella, Jeanie and two boys. Had a good time, and as I had to return to Edinburgh that night I had to leave Glasgow at 5 pm. Arr Edinburgh 7pm. Supper at Aunt Jess’s. Caught the London Express from Waverley at 10pm
Entry.8:
LONDON

Wareham riot Piquet

Arr.London 8am and as the Amesbury train did not leave Waterloo till 5.50pm we spent the time seeing the sights of London. Arrived Amesbury about 8.30pm, then had a three or four mile march back to Larkhill camp, which we reached at 9.45 pm.Glad to get into bed as we had been walking all day.
Entry.9:
Larkhill

Wareham Riot Piquet

Revielle 6.30am

Stables 6.45am

Till about 7.45am

Breakfast

Stables 8.30

Teams went out about 9.30 till noon

Dinner

Stables 1.30pm

Till 2.30

Harness cleaning

2.30 till 3.30

Stables 3.30 till 5pm

Harness inspection at 5.15pm

Tea 5.30pm

Soup 8pm

Lights out 10.15 pm

Larkhill
Entry.10: Put on as stableman for one week
Entry.11:
Larkhill Camp

 Medical examination Passed A
Entry.12:
Larkhill

Stableman 

Have to clean out stables and mix up the feeds for about 35 or 40 Horses. Hours
Entry.13:
am till 5pm

Letter from C.W.Banks re telegraphic remittance.
Entry.15:
Larkhill

Received letter from Commonwealth Bank of Australia London re telegraphic remittance of 5pounds from Australia
Entry.16: Stable piquet at 4.45pm till 7am next morning.
Entry.18: Table piquet at 4.30pm till 7am next morning
Entry.20:
Neg 1 copy of each

2Neg 12 copies of each’
Entry.22:
total

28 prints for Mac

28 prints for R.O.E

26 prints for JWM

Tuesday 13th March 1917

Larkhill

Thursday 15th March 1917

John and I warned for Draft
Entry.24: Instructions in the use of Gas helmet. Australians captured Bapaume (France)
Entry.25: Busy all day washing and mending getting ready for Draft.
Entry.26:
Went through the gas test this morning. Helmets on and put into the gas chamber for two or three minutes. Medical inspection in the afternoon, then issued with 24 hours rations. (6 biscuits, 1tin sardines and 1 pound tin of meat).

Left Larkhill camp at 11pm. Arr. Amesbury station about 1am. Left Amesbury 1.15am and arr.Folkestone 7am the next morning. Before leaving camp issued with 1lb. tin meat 1tin sardines and 6 biscuits.
Entry.27:
Folkestone

Arrived Folkestone 7am. Taken to the Victoria Hotel (which is used as Barracks) and given a good breakfast of porridge, ham, bread and tea. Embarked at 8.45am and sailed about 9.50am. Escort one destroyer. Arrived Boulogne about 11.45am. Disembarked about 12.30am and marched to a rest camp outside Boulogne about 1 mile from the city 3pm. Tea, bread,jam and cheese
Entry.28:
Boulogne (France)

The Artillery (about 200) all slept in the same hut. Revielle 6am.Breakfast 7am (bacon, cheese, jam and tin meat, bread and tea). Issued with rations, 1tin meat, biscuits and cheese and marched off about 10am, arr Boulogne station 10.30am. Put into trucks and left about 11.50am.

Arr. Etaples (E-taps) about 1.20pm then marched to camp about 2 mls. From station. Slept in Bell tent 12 men in each tent.
Entry.29:
Etaples (E-taps)

Revielle, 5.30am

First parade 6.15am

Breakfast 6.45am

2nd Parade

Diner 12 noon till2pm

Dismissed about 2.30pm. Issued with steel helmets and gas helmets
Entry.30:
Etaples

Left camp about 8.30am and marched to Bull ring where we were given a lecture on the use of Box H.P.Gas helmets. After lunch went through the gas and tear trench. Arrived back in camp about 4pm.

 

Saturday 34th March 1917

At 9pm light out sounded at the double searchlights playing over our camp, said to be a Zep about. Left camp at 8am had as four mile march to Kangaroo range, where we had a lecture on the cleaning of rifles, then fired 15 rounds. Left the range at 12 noon and arrived in camp at 1.20pm. Accident in camp while waiting to enter Mess Hut, earth gave way over sewerage and 3 men went down (20ft) they were got out but one died.

On account of daylight saving, had to put watch on one hour. Church parade at 9am, parade at 2pm. Warned for draft not allowed to leave lines.
Entry.31:
Etaples

Final medical examination before going to the firing line. Concert at the Y.M.C.A Hut in the evening.

Met Len. Georges of Malvern on Saturday evening
Entry.32: at a concert in the Y.M.C.A. Hut. Greatly surprised to see John and I, came round to our tent the next evening
Entry.34:
Etaples

Issued with underclothing, cardigan, sheepskin mittens. After that had a good hot bath. Goodness knows when will get another.

28 Wed

The rumble of gun fire can be heard from this camp (Albert). The Rly station and nearly every building I passed was damaged by shell fire.
Entry.35:
Etaples

Revielle, 4.30am

Breakfast 5am

 Fall in 5.45am marched out of Etaples camp 6.45am arr. Rly. Station about 7.15am entrained and left at 10.25am arr.Abbeville 12.25 and stopped there for 15 min.Arr. Longpre 1.20pm sighted Albert Cathedral about 5.45pm recognised by the Virgin Mary on top lying at right angles to the building caused by German Shell fire (15th Jan.1915). Arr. rest camp 6.30pm (about 1 ½ mls. from the station). Slept in Bell tent for the night
Entry.36:
Albert

Albert Camp

After going through Gas drill, we left camp about 9am, then had about 5 mls. To march to La Boiselle camp arr about 2pm. Dinner then dismissed for the day

 

La Boiselle Camp 

Revielle 6.30am fall in 7am. Fed mules, then breakfast next parade 9am. Went out mounted with wagon to cart ammunition, 3 hrs. ride before we arr. at dump. Wheel came off so returned to camp as we could only fix it temporally, arr. aback 6.30pm. Passed Pozieres or what was left of it. (only a few tree stumps Passed about 6 tanks and 2 aeroplanes lying near the road. All destroyed. Allotted to the 4th Section
Entry.38:
La Boiselle

Stables all day Finished duty 4.30pm then had a walk through the trenches and dugouts outside of Pozieres.
Entry.39: Sick parade in morning shifted into Right section hut.
Entry.40:
Grooming "Donks" in the morning and cleaning harness in the afternoon.

Pozieres is the gravestone of as many of our troops as we lost in the whole Gallipoli campaign and what the Australians did there ought to live in the history of this war for ever. The Tommies took the place 3 times and could not hold it under the heavy artillery fire and counter attacks. They brought our Boys all the way from Ypres to get it and they got it, held it, and after five days pushed old Fritz right over the next ridge and old Fritz has never retaken an inch from our boys yet. 

Say a man starts once walk from La Boiselle along to Pozieres, he walks on the ruins of shell holes (level ground is unheard of) numbers of them, the graves of unknown soldiers, equipment strewn all over the place, broken stretchers, helmets, bombs and unexploded shells.

 

Tuesday 3rd April 1917

Grooming and cleaning harnesses all day.

Paid 40 franks

Pozieres (cont)

by dozens from the little 12 pounder up to the immense 15 inch. You stumble through barbed wire (some of it German with sharp iron spikes put in the ground under it). When you arrive at Pozieres you would not think that at one time it was a peaceful village. All that is left is heaps of bricks and timber, and all the trees has been blown to pieces by shell fire.

1st Div. took Pozieres
Entry.42:
Two or three German aeroplanes passed over our camp. Great number of shots fired by anti-aircraft guns. The aeroplanes were not hit, but returned to their own lines.

In the evening two of our balloons (spotters) were brought down by the Germans.
Entry.43:
La Boiselle

Marched to Martinbuich in the morning, taking ammunition out of the dugout and running it down on a light railway to a station. Took piece of shrapnel out of cross in cemetry. Arr. back to camp about 5pm.
Entry.44:
Hut Orderley

After cleaning hut I spent the rest of the day washing.
Entry.45: Grooming and harness cleaning. Inspection of stables by General Johnson.
Entry.46: Grooming "Donks" in the morning harness cleaning in the afternoon
Entry.47:
Several lines crossed out. 

Cleaning harnesses all day.

 

La Boiselle

Harnessed up team and went into Albert but returned empty as we were not required. Arr. camp about 1pm. 

At 2pm we packed kits, as we were leaving La Boiselle that afternoon. Put our kits in the waggon and left 3.30pm. Arr. Bapeaume about 7 pm. After attending the horses etc. (in snow storm) we had to find a place to sleep (no tents or huts) Slept under an old motor cover. Tarp on top. As we were tired we slept A1
Entry.48:
Bapeaume

Fixing the "Donk" lines and racks for the harness. After dinner, took a load of ammunition (18lb.shrapnell) to the forward dump. Arr. back in camp about 6pm. Camped just beside sugar refining works, (which is like the rest of the town in ruins. Town in awful state so far I have not seen a house that has escaped the terrible shell force)
Entry.49:
Building a hut for John and self, with empty ammunition boxes. Kept going till about 6pm. Got it very comfortable, plenty of hay on the floor and have a good fire inside so we are A, hut about 8x6

Australians were the first to enter Bapaume. In the small hours of St Patricks day, Australian patrols found that the German were retiring from the trenches north of Bapaume and by 6 o’clock N.S.W.and Victorian troops were well out into the country behind the German lines.2 hrs. Later troops of a battalion drawn from all Australian States penetrated into Bapaume. With the

 

Bapaume 

taking of Bapaume the Australians have left the Somme battlefields with its frightful shell shattered surface, definitely behind them and are in green country.

Grooming "Donks" in the morning. Fatague work in the afternoon. While gathering firewood shell passed over head and exploded about 200 yds. away.
Entry.50: Grooming in the morning. Fritz shelling township no damage done except piece of shell struck railway engine boiler. Carting ammunition to forward dump.
Entry.51: Loading wagons wit ammunition and ready for taking away but orders cancelled, cleaning harness in the afternoon.
Entry.52:
Bapaume

Grooming in the morning and had just started cleaning harness about 2.30pm when we had to leave the lines as a few of Fritz shells landed near the mules, so we ran back and took them about a mile to a flank, as our camp was in the line of fire. Another shell landed about 50 feet away from the wagons loaded with ammunition, but did not damage it. Returned to camp in about an hour and a half, put rugs on mules and fixed up new lines, about a mile away. As it was too late to shift out huts we slept in them that 

 

 (Received parcel from Jess)

Mon.16 cont.

night. Picked up a piece of the shells that fell near wagons. Boys reckon that it is 9.2 that Fritz is sending over. None injured. Boys quiet pleased that they have not got to shift their huts that night.
Entry.53: Clearing everything away from old camp, as no one allowed to sleep there that night. Mule lines, huts etc. fixed by night.
Entry.54:
Received socks from Aline, and letter from Com. Bank.

John and I harnessed up four mules as we have to go near the firing line for a waggon load with bombs, and take them to the dump just behind Gun pits.

Picked up wagon at Vaux and got the bombs through without any trouble. This waggon had gone up the night before but part of the body got mashed so drivers unloaded, and left wagons at the side of the road. Arr. back in camp at 4.30pm.

Paid 40 francs
Entry.55:
Cleaning up old camp ground. Burning the straw, putting empty tins in shell holes, and getting a waggon load of timber for cooks.

Harness cleaning and greasing waggon wheels in the afternoon.
Entry.56:
Bapaume 

Cleaning up hut lines of B Sub.

In the afternoon took mules out in the field and let them go for about one hour and a half.

Sent letter to Commwlth. Bank London re telegraphic remittance from Australia
Entry.57:
Bapaume

Revielle 5.30am as a few teams have to go out early. Harness cleaning and grooming the rest of the day.
Entry.58:
Went out with teams at 9am. Took load of Bombs from dump to dugouts near firing. Very heavy roads mud up to the axles in death trap gully. While waiting to have waggon unloaded went up on parapet to have a look at front line. Only there a few seconds when a whizz-bang landed about 10 ft. away so I came down onto the road again quick and lively.

 

Sunday 22nd 1917

While standing there our aeroplanes were flying over our heads, observing and Fritz was sending shrapnel at them so we had a warm time. After discharging our load of bombs at Noreuil and returning through Death trap gully Fritz started to send shrapnel over so we got out of there as quick as possible. Got back to camp about 2.30pm all safe.
Entry.60:
Bapaume

Harness cleaning and grooming.

Took a load of broken wheels to ordinance store outside Bapaume.

About a dozen observation Balloons up today (called "sausage" or "spotters" by the boys). They suggest some antediluvian animal rather than an appliance of modern warfare. These balloons are not dirigible; they are controlled by a powerful hawser attached to a tractor engine, which can pull them back to earth with wonderful speed when attacking aircraft are sighted.

 

Wednesday 25th
Entry.61:
In the morning Grooming and harness cleaning.

Harness cleaning and scraping mud off wagons in the afternoon.
Entry.62:
Bapaume 

Left camp about 9.30am and went up to Death Trap Gully (near Vaux) to one of the Battery’s for a load of empty shell cases and brought them back to the forward dump. Gully very quiet. Arrived back about 3pm.

In coming home I met one of my old ship mates (Jack Taylor) who left Glasgow the same time as myself, in1910, but lost the run of him in Melb. 2 years ago.
Entry.63:
Grooming and harness cleaning.

As one approaches the firing line for the first time, the spectacle is inspiring, thrilling and often nerve-racking. Hundreds of shells from our field batteries and 60 lbders whistle continually overhead on their errands of destruction towards the German lines. The fields everywhere are ploughed up with shell craters. The roads are continually being damaged, billets and farmhouses are in ruins, while working parties of hundreds, and even thousands are constantly repairing the roads. You may walk by a hedge, fence or a thicket and never dream that it masks an entire battery.

We have all grown accustomed to the many disguises such as painting the guns to resemble branches and trunks of trees. Unless one has been in the battle zone it is impossible to realise how cleverly the guns are masked.
Entry.64:
Bapaume

Grooming and harness cleaning.

Football match between Right and Left sections.

Right section won by
Entry.65:
Church service at 11 am

Football match 2nd D.A.C.vs

Recd. letter from Comm.Bank

 

Revielle 5.30am

Harnessed up and ready to move out at 7.30am

In the morning we took two loads of empty shells from dump to near railway line, and in the afternoon two loads of empty boxes to sand place.
Entry.66:
Bapaume

Watered mules then gave them a run on the grabs till 11.30 am

Cleaning up the mule lines in the afternoon.

Paid 40 francs on e shilling and four pence left.

Line Piquet at 5.15pm while taking of nose bags one of the mules took a liking to me and let fly his two hind legs. I got them all right so the Piquet had to get another man.
Entry.67:
Leg stiff went up to Doctor.

No duty for two days have to report to the Doctor on Friday morning.

After dusk our guns started a very heavy bombardment, which was kept up all night. I am told that the great push starts tonight.

This morning the Boys took most of our "Donks" up the line to the batteries as they were short of horses.
Entry.68:
Bapaume

No Duty

Reveille 3.30 am Donks fed and two or three teams went out about 5am.

About this part of France, which the enemy has been forced to abandon, there is no beauty left and no homesteads or farms but only black ruins and devastation everywhere.

The enemy is adopting the full cruelty of wars malignancy. He has poisoned the wells in his wake, so that if our soldiers horses should drink there they will die. Roads have been mined, opening up enormous craters to retard our transport on the road. 

The Taube must have been looking for our Rly. Line and Ammunition dump but he had no luck. While running out of camp 2 or 3 boys fell into barbed wire
Entry.69:
Reveille 7am

No parade till 9am as we have no Donks to feed.

Went to Doctor this morning. Exempt from duty, so spent the day writing letters.

Just on lights out (9,30pm) a Taube flew over our camp (very low). It was flying about for nearly 5 minutes and in that time dropped three bombs. It again came towards our camp, so we got out of the camp. Did not drop any more bombs, as our Anti-aircraft guns opened out on it also some of the boys with rifles.
Entry.70:
Bapaume

Visited the cemetery

Reveille 7am

First Parade 9am

Lectures on harness cleaning and fitting by the S.M.

After roll call at 2pm we were dismissed till 4pm. Unloaded a few waggons, which only took a few minutes. Then dismissed for the day.
Entry.71:
Reveille 6.30am

1st parade 7am

Oiling waggons and cleaning up lines.
Entry.72: Cleaning lines in the morning. And in the afternoon put on cleaning and oining waggons.
Entry.73:
Bapaume

Cleaning and oiling harness. Did not get dismissed till 6pm

Very heavy rain all night. Did not stop till about 1pm today.
Entry.75:
Bapaume

Harnessed up team and left park at 8am. Went to Dump at Vaux for a load of empty shell cases. While waiting there Fritz started shelling. Arrived back in camp about 11am.

Went for another load in the afternoon and left them beside the railway line which runs alongside out camp.
Entry.76: Washing harness, and painting the harness racks of "B" Sub
Entry.77: Cleaning harness, and painting "A" Sub harness racks.
Entry.78:
Went to dentist.

No parade at 2pm fell in at 4pm to feed mules. Went out as centre driver at 7pm. Loaded waggons with timber and sand bags (at Bapaume) for machine gun pits and dug outs for gunners.

nr Lagnecourt

 

Sunday cont.

Arr. at Vaulx about 8.30pm and had to wait there till dark as the rest of our journey (about 3-4 kilom.) was open country answer could be seen by the enemy. Stopped about 20 min. when a slight fog came down, so we advanced. Left our load at the 11th battery. One of the gunners killed about an hour before. Fritz very quiet but he started to shell Vaulx as we returned home. Arr. camp at 11pm.
Entry.79:
Recd. letter from Com. Bank saying remittances sent home 26th.

Cleaning up the lines, and oiling harness. 2pm Taube overhead. Fired at by our guns. I thought it was hit as it came down 2 or 3 thousand feet turning over and over but as soon as he got into the clouds he made off.
Entry.80:
Cleaning harness.

Sent letter to C.W.Bank saying that money not received.
Entry.83:
Cleaning stirrup irons all day.

Left camp about 7pm with team. Went to Enges Dump at Vaux where we got a load of barbed wire and spikes which we had to take up to the support at Lagnecourt. Had a good trip up, but coming back it was dark and as I was lead driver it was hard to see the shell holes in the road. By the time we reached Vaux it was so dark that I could hardly see the road passing through the village and one of Fritz shells landed near our wagon, mules bolted but we soon had them in hand.
Entry.84:
Bapaume

Cleaning lines.

Left camp about 10am and went to Dump at Favreuil. Filling boxes with empty 18lb. shell cases and stacking. Came back to camp for dinner in the afternoon.
Entry.85:
Left camp at 9am for dump.

Took dinner with me.

Arr. back in camp about 5.30pm.
Entry.86:
Left camp about 9am for Dump at Favreuil.

In the morning we loaded motor waggons with empty cases.

In the afternoon we finished the staking and cleaning up.

At dinner time I had a walk through Fritz grave yard and one strange thing I noticed was that all the dates were cut of the crosses.

 

Monday cont.

Left camp at 8pm (40 men) and were driven in G.S. Waggons to the Gully near Noreuil where we were having to dig a trench from HQ to the Battererys for cables. As they wanted 400 men and our 40 were the only ones there, we were put on another job. Taking damaged shells from the battery and putting them in a shell hole. While there, there was a stunt on, the gully was lit up by the flares fired in the front line and our artillery was giving Fritzy hell. 

We finished at midnight and coming home we a good cup of tea and a packet of biscuits at the YMCA (free buffet). We then had a six mile walk before us but we were lucky in getting a lift in a motor wagon to Bapaume. Arr camp 1.40am.
Entry.88:
Watching mules while grazing.

Cleaning harness in the afternoon and stable Piquet at 6pm. On 3rd shift (2 till 4am)

One of Fritzs’planes over our camp at 5am this morning but had to return to his own lines as our guns made it too hot for him.
Entry.91:
Bapaume

Cleaning harness.

Wrote to Mother and Jessie
Entry.92:
Cleaning harness

Got back my two mules this morning.

Expect to move camp tomorrow so packed our kits.
Entry.93:
9am till11am pulling down our huts and cleaning up. 

Harnessed up team and went out with G.S.Waggon about 3pm. Took 48 hours rations for self and donks. Went to the 104th Horse battery, wagon lines at Favreuil as there are going out in the morning for a spell and we have to cart some of their baggage. Only 2G.S. Waggons came to this battery. While walking through one of the other batteries I met W. Herbert Crawley and Billy Herbert and one or two more of the "Boys" that came over on the "Borda" from Melb.

Slept under the waggon.
Entry.94:
Favreuil

Reveille 4am

Took mules to water and fed up. Loaded our waggons with batteries baggage and moved out at 8.30 am. Picked up other 2nd Div. batteries on the road (who were also coming out) and by the time we reached La Boiselle we must have been over a mile long. Arr. at a camp about 2 mls. out of Albert at 1.30pm.

Slept under waggon.
Entry.95:
Nr Pozieres

Harnessed up about 8.30 am and moved out a little after 9am.

Arr, at our destination about 10.30 am and unloaded some of the baggage.

Nothing to do for the rest of the day except attend to the "Donks". Met Fred Williams (of Malvern) in the afternoon.
Entry.96:
Nr Pozieres Aveluy

Got out of bed about 8am. Watered and fed mules as we have to return to our own unit, we harnessed up about 1pm,emptied our waggon and moved out at 2pm. Picked up our own unit at 3pm which were camped near Bouzincourt (nr. Albert).
Entry.97:
Nr Bouzincourt

Reveille 5.30am

Put waggons in line. Breakfast 7am.Cleaning lines and harness cleaning till 12 noon.

2 till 5pm Harness cleaning.

After tea went for a swim in lake about 1 ½ mls from our camp. (The first swim I have had since leaving Australia) (but not the first wash).
Entry.98:
Aveluy nr. Bouzincourt 

Reveille 5.30am.

First parade 6am and water mules. Breakfast 7 till 9am then cleaning harness and water mules. Dinner 12 till 2pm. At 2pm we marched to the baths at Bouzincourt, where we had a good hot bath and a change of underclothing.

Sunday 3rd

Rev. 5am

2nd Div. church parade at 8.30am and inspection by General Johnson.

Dinner 12 till 3.30pm
Entry.99: As the 2nd Division is to be inspected by Gen. Birdwood tomorrow we had a practice this morning.
Entry.100:
past Gen. Johnson.

Harness and waggons ready for tomorrow.
Entry.101:
Aveluy nr Bouzincourt .

Inspections of 2nd Div. Artillery by General Birdwood this morning.

Our O.C. (Leut.Gouldin) thanked the boys the way they worked on their harness etc. and the splendid way they carried out their work during the Review.
Entry.102:
Reveille 6am

Dinner 12 noon next parade 3.30 pm.

Went to picture show at night at Bouzincourt.
Entry.103:
Aveluy nr Bouzincourt .

Rifle drill in the morning and harness cleaning in the afternoon.
Entry.104: Rifle drill in the morning and harness cleaning in the afternoon.
Entry.105:
Aveluy nr Bouzincourt

Harness cleaning Half holiday.
Entry.106:
Church parade and sports in the afternoon.

Stable piquet at 6pm

 

Monday11th
Entry.107: Raining very heavy this morning so we cleaned our harness in the huts.
Entry.108:
Aveluy nr Boizincourt

Grooming and cleaning harness
Entry.109: Amiens leave. Left camp about 7.15 am and walked to Albert station where I got the train. Left Albert 8.30 arr. Ameins 9.30am. After having a good look round and visited the Cathedral we left at 8 pm. Arr. back at camp at 10pm
Entry.110:
Aveluy nr Boizincourt

Grooming and cleaning harness
Entry.112:
Aveluy nr Boizincourt

Harness cleaning all day.
Entry.113: Grooming and harness cleaning and building officers mess hut in the afternoon
Entry.114:
Grooming and harness cleaning. Half-holiday in the afternoon 

 

Aveluy nr Boizincourt

Revielle 5am first parade 5.30am

Watered and fed "Donks"

Breakfast 7am
Entry.115: parade 9am but were dismissed on account of heavy rain.
Entry.116: Grooming and harness cleaning for marching order parade.
Entry.117:
Amiens

Amiens leave. Left camp about 7.30am. Arrived back in camp at 10pm.
Entry.118:
Harness cleaning.

Sent registered letter to Jeanie
Entry.119:
Aveluy

Harness cleaning.

Mounted stable piquet at 6pm got the 3rd shift 2 till4pm
Entry.120: Church Parade at 9am. Left camp at 1.30pm for a hot bath at Bouzincourt
Entry.123:
Went to dentist this morning. Left camp at 9am with "Donk" as I had to go to Bell view farm hospital which is on the outskirts of Albert. Arrived there about 10am. Got fixed up at 12 noon then had a ride through Albert,arr. back in camp about 3pm.

2nd Div. sports today but I did not go as I was too late in getting back to camp.
Entry.128:
Aveluy

Dental leave to Bell farm
Entry.130:
Aveluy

Harness cleaning. Half holiday from 12 to 4pm
Entry.131:
Grooming and harness cleaning.

Went to concert at Bouzincourt (Anzac Coves)

Good concert General Johnson and all the heads there.
Entry.133:
Painting waggons.

Half holiday from 12 to 4pm
Entry.134: No church parade on account of rain second division moving out tomorrow our section busy packing.
Entry.135:
Orville

Reveille 3am.

Stables 3.30 breakfast 4am and ready to move out by 5am. Did not move out till near 6am. Going north. Arrived Orville about 12 noon. Harness off and watered mules. Good stables. After billeted in large brick building. Had a good feed of fried eggs, bread and butter. Got to bed about 9pm.
Entry.136:
Rebrueviette

Reveille 4.30 am stables, breakfast, first parade 5.30am harnessed up and moved about 7am. Had a very stiff hill to pull up for a start. Passed through some lovely country.

Arr. Rebrueviette about 2pm. Unharnessed and took donks to water by the time we came back the gunners had the lines ready so fed up and were dismissed till 3pm. Billet very poor.
Entry.137:
Foufflin-Ricametz

Reveille 4.30, Breakfast 5,, stables 5.30am and harnesses up and ready to move off at 6.30am. Arr. Foufflin-Ricametz about 1pm. Watered and fed mules.

The country we came through was all cultivated and with the trees all scatted about it looked A1.

Arr. at our billet about noon, which was a large house of about 12 rooms, lovely avenue leading up to the house used avenue for mule lines.
Entry.138:
Fouffin-Ricametz

Reveille 6am. Had breakfast, then started to fill nose bags hay nets as I am stable-man for the day. Dinner 12 noon.

"Donks" went to water at 11.30am did not return till about 2.30pm.

Had one da spell here. Plenty of current bushes in the grounds, but not very many left when we’d finished.
Entry.139:
Nedon

Reveille 5am, left Fouffin-Ricametz at 6.30am.

Arr. Nedon at noon the billets were very poor. I slept out in the open near the wagons.
Entry.140:
Aire

Left Nedon 6am and arrived Aire 1pm. Very heavy rain about 9am. About noon we arrived at a small village just outside Aire. Billeted in a shed at a large farm. Had a swim in the canal after tea.
Entry.141: Left Aire 4.30am and arrived outside Cassel about 9am. Had an A1 feed of eggs at the village.
Entry.142:
Cassel

 Rev. 2.30am left Cassel about 3.30am and arrived Godewaersveld about 2pm.
Entry.143:
Godewaersvelds

Rev 2.30am

Left Godewaersveld at 5am and arrived Dickebusch about 9am.

After dinner made a shelter to sleep in.

 

Wednesday 18th July 1917

Dickebusch (Belgium)

Rev. 6.30am

First Parade 7am

Watered and fed donks.

Breakfast.

2nd parade at 9.30am, grooming and fixing waggons and lines.

Dinner
Entry.146:
Dickebusch

Grooming and fixing harness racks.

Old Fritz sent over a few large shells after lights out and about 4am. A few of them landed near head quarters.

 

Saturday 21st July 1917

Took wagon to Busseboom for a load of timber forth 13th battery. Left camp at 12 noon and arrived back at the
Entry.147: battery about 4pm where we left wagon.
Entry.148: Great number of our searchlights sweeping the sky looking for Fritz planes. Lovely sight. Half holiday from12noon to 3pm. About 10.30pm a few of Fritz planes dropped bombs around our camp for nearly ½ hour. No damage done.
Entry.149:
Dickebusch

Cleaning and oiling waggons in the morning.

Washing harness in the afternoon.
Entry.150: Grooming and harness cleaning. About 5am this morning one of Fritz planes flew over our camp, but managed to escape our gun fire.
Entry.151:
Dickebusch

Grooming and harness cleaning.

Mounted guard at 6pm on first shift.
Entry.152:
Came of guard at 6pm.

At 9.30pm I was warned to go out with team at midnight but the guard came round at midnight and said that we would not be wanted till 5am.

About 11.30pm 2 of Fritz planes dropped bombs near our camp.

 

Friday 27th July 1917

2 or 3 Fritz planes came over dropped bombs all round and missed us.

Guard woke me up at 5am, fed mules and put harness on, then had breakfast. Left camp at 6am and reported to the
Entry.153:
battery about 6.10am. 

was in charge of us has no pass for our team, to proceed to the gun position. Day finish 7.30pm. Just heard that Doug Reynolds killed, Bishop wounded.
Entry.154:
Dickebusch

Grooming and harness cleaning. Shortly after midnight the camp was roused as Fritz was sending Gas shells over to Dickebusch and we got a wiff of it. As it got very strong I put on my mask for an ½ hour. Boys coughing and sneezing.
Entry.155: Left camp about 6am and marched to Reninghelst where we had a good hot bath. Left baths at 9.30 am very heavy storm was drenched coming home.
Entry.156:
Dickebusch

Cleaning harness.

Guns very quiet in the early part of the evening. Now and again our camp would get a shake as a 13.2 naval was fired.

Stunt started about midnight. In an instant the air and earth shook and the whole horizon blazed as our 100s of guns broke at once.

The horizon was rimmed with flickering flare of every tint of yellow down to the dull red glow of burning oil with the shock and clamour of the guns of the guns it was thrilling beyond words.
Entry.157:
Great number of German prisoners being brought down from the line. Very heavy gunfire all night. Heard we had a good advance our guns still going strong this morning.

Very heavy bombardment about 10pm. It seemed as if 10,000 shells a minute were fired. The dark, cloudy morning is as bright as one of our well lit streets.
Entry.158:
Very heavy rain so were cleaning harness all morning in our dugout.

Guns very quiet.

1.30pm ordered to harness up. 2pm left camp and went to sawmills at Reninghelst for timber. Roads very muddy and by the time I got back to camp (5pm) I was covered in mud.

First rum issue.
Entry.159:
Still raining, Guns very quiet.

Exercising mules from 9 till 11.30am
Entry.160:
Dickebusch

Still raining. Exercised mules from 9 till 11.30am.

Harness cleaning in the afternoon.
Entry.163:
Cleaning lines and grooming.

 

Cleaning lines and grooming.
Entry.164: Harnessed up and moved out of camp by 8am. Brought three loads of bricks from Dickebusch in the morning. Went to ordinance at Reninghelst with H.Q. Quartermaster in the afternoon arrived back at camp about 6.30pm.
Entry.165:
6.30 am Taube over camp dropped two bombs injuring Turner, Wilber Ashley. 4 horses and 10 donks were so badly injured that they had to be shot. Donks and horses were skinned and I was one of the burying party. Got them all buried by 5.30pm. The bombs made very small holes.

1.30pm one of Fritz planes set fire to one of our observing balloons about 5minutes later our planes set one of Fritz balloons on fire.
Entry.166:
Cleaning lines.

Harness cleaning in the afternoon
Entry.167: Harnessed up and moved out of camp by 8am brought four loads of old bricks from Dickebusch to "C" sub lines.
Entry.168: Mounted stable piquet at 6pm filled nose bags 3rd shift till 4am.
Entry.169:
Dickebusch.

Cleaning lines and washing harness.
Entry.170: Carting bricks from Dickebusch to mule lines.
Entry.172: Harnessed up and moved out by 9am. Carting bricks from Dickebusch to "C" sub lines
Entry.173:
Dickebusch

Grooming and harness cleaning.

Fritz planes came over about 9.30pm. Dropped great number of bombs.

Our search lights playing all over the show.
Entry.174:
Grooming and harness cleaning.

Taubes over about 9.30pm

Sky lit up by our search lights, got on to a Taube. Guns gave him a hot time but he managed to get away.
Entry.175:
9.30 pm Taubes over dropping bombs.

Church service 10am.

Half holiday. Harnessed up wheelers about 3pm went to H.Q. for comforts. One of Fritz planes brought down near camp by anti-aircraft guns.
Entry.176:
Dickebusch

Harnessed up by 8am. Carting bricks from Dickebusch to road backing onto camp.

Aircraft got one of Fritz planes at 9am. There were two flying over lines and one of them burst into flames. The aviator managed to plane down but when near the earth he took a dive must have struck the ground with great force. Taube over at 9.30pm very few bombs dropped.
Entry.177: Cleaning harness. Ted Holbrook wheel driver went on leave.
Entry.178:
Dickebusch

Harnessed and moved out by 8am. Went to Spoil Bank (nr. 18lb gun pits) for a load of old ammunition (18lbs) and brought it back to dump at Dickebusch.

On the road up we passed great number of naval and other heavy guns. You may drive past a hedge or a thicket and never dream that it masks an entire battery so cleverly are the guns masked. Another trip to the same place in the afternoon finished about 6pm.

10pm Tube over with lights but he returned very quick as our guns got on to him.
Entry.179: Harnessed up and moved out by 9am. Carting bricks from Dickebusch to 15th Battery
Entry.180:
Dickebusch

Putting bricks in mule lines.
Entry.181: Took two pack mules to nr. Shrapnel corner taking away 18lb ammunition from old pits and dumping it at the side of the road. Seven Taubes flew overhead just as we were knocking off. Dropped bombs very close. Arr. camp about 6 pm.
Entry.182: Grooming and cleaning lines. Half holiday 12 till 4pm. Very heavy rain at 10pm.
Entry.183:
Dickebusch

Harnessed up and moved out by 8am. Took a load of timber from saw mills(nr Reninghelst) to Dump (nr.Ypres) got back to camp about 1pm. Harnessed up again at 2pm carting bricks from Dickebusch to "B" sub lines. Fritz shelling Dickebusch.
Entry.185:
Dickebusch

Took waggon to 105th waggon lines at 9am.

Left there about 9.30am and went up to 105th pits for a load of empty shell cases. Brought them back for another load which I’ve brought to dump to near camp. Very quiet at Pits, but Fritz making it very hot near Shrapnel Corner. Very rough road near pit. Driving through shell holes. Get back to camp about 6pm.
Entry.186:
Grooming in the morning. Went to baths at Dickebusch about 1.30pm

Got back in time to feed up.
Entry.188: Went out in W. Flinns team as lead driver carting 4.5s from Spoil Bank to Dump near camp. One load in the morning and one in the afternoon.
Entry.189:
Fed mules in the morning 2nd parade 10 am. Church service 10.30am. 3rd parade 4pm.

10pm Tubes dropping bombs. They kept coming over till about 3.30am.
Entry.190:
Dickebusch

Left camp about 8.30am with 2 pack mules arr. Spoil Bunk about 10 am where we salvaged 4.5 howz. from old battery position and tool them to the roadside. Dinner 12 til l2 finished about 2.30pm. Brought 4 shells back to dump (near our camp) on off mule.

Fritz shelling very heavy about a mile to the right of us.

Taubes a bit quieter tonight. Our planes had a box with a Taube.
Entry.193:
Put my few mules on the grass 1pm, watching mules grazing about 3pm 5 or 6 Taubes came over and dropped bombs very close to camp. Everyone got under cover and the donks I was watching took fright and galloped back to lines. I was too far away from dugout, so I got among the trees. No bombs dropped in our camp but fell very close. As it was very cloudy the guns had difficulty in picking him out.

 

No entry for
Entry.195: Grooming and harness cleaning, five or six Taubes over dropping bombs, but all fell well away from our camp.
Entry.196: Church Parade 10am. 12 noon watered and fed mules. N.F. band played selection in our lines from 2pm till 3.30pm
Entry.197:
September1917

Dickebrusch

Reveille 5am

First parade 5.15am. Fed mules then loaded wagons with ammunition as we moved to another position today. Harnessed up and moved out at 11.45am. Officers hid in our waggon. After a few stops on the road we arrived at our new camp about two Kilos from Reninghelst about 2pm, had dinner then back to old camp for a load of timber. Arr. home about 10pm
Entry.198:
Nr. Reninghelst

Grooming. Building harness racks and fixing mules lines.

 

Nr. Reninghelst

Grooming and harness cleaning

Taubes having a fly over near our lines. Both sides have the aircraft to a wonderful stage of perfection and there is no finer site than to see an engagement, when they get into close quarters, then some marvellous manoeuvers and the machine guns begin to talk from both planes, a sheet of flame, an object taking a header, then quiet.
Entry.201: Church parade 10am. Watered and fed mules then dismissed till 4pm. Warned to go out with team in the morning at 2.15am
Entry.202:
Nr Reninghelst

2.15am harnessed up and moved out of the camp by 3am (6 teams). 

Went through Dickebusch and Ypres. Fritz shelling Ypres, not a building has escaped the terrible shell fire. The Cathedral and clotlehall are in ruins. Filled our wagons with sleepers steel girders etc. For 10th Battery gun pits about ½ mile passed Hell fire corner. Dead horses, mules,metal wagons and timbers lying all over the place. Fritz sending over coal boxes, and old rubber gut into Ypres. Arr. back I camp about 11.45am
Entry.203:
Mounted waggon and dump guard last night at 6pm on second shift 8till 10pm and 2 till 4am

Painting and printing boards for O.C.
Entry.205:
September1917

Harness up moved out of camp by 12 noon. Went to ordanance (nr Poperinghi) with a load of damaged waggon wheels. Arr ordanance about 3pm where we were unloaded by china men. Passed through some beautiful country civilians going on with their work in the fields as if there was no war on. Got back to camp about 4.30pm. Our guns opened up about 8pm. Skyline lit up by the flashes
Entry.206:
Grooming and harness cleaning. Letter from Gen Birdwood read out in orders praising up the 2nd Division on their good work, especially last night when they pushed Fritz back and got their objective in about 7 minutes.

8.30pm Taube over dropped bombs not far from camp. Got undercover quick and lively. Piece of shrapnel from aircraft struck out tarpaulin made a hole but did not come through (got the piece).
Entry.207:
Painting number and rising suns on our wagons also notice board for officers quarters.

Sunday 23rd

Painting notice boards for officers quarters. Football match between B. Echelon and 2nd section, 107 to 15 points B.E over
Entry.209:
Nr Reninchelst

Returned E. Aulerbrooks letters to Post office (10) and kit, box gas helmet and overcoat to Q.M.

Painting notice boards for officers quarters.
Entry.210:
Painting notice boards for Officers quarters2pm left camp with waggon. Arrived Howe Dump about 4pm where we took on a load of ammunination for 105th Batter, Very heavy traffic going through Ypres. It took us about two hours getting through.

 After a great number of stoppages we arr at battery about 8pm. Fritz shelling us going home a few landed in front of us and we had a great job trying to dodge the shell holes. When we got on road we had to pass through the 2 smouldering timber of a dump (which Fritz had dropped a shell into it about 20 minutes before). A few yards further on the road blocked with wagons, timbers etc (all knocked about with Fritz shells) tried for about ½ hour to get clear but impossible so unhooked donks and left waggon as the shells were landing all around us. Seven of our wagons were left there. After a exciting time we arr back in camp at midnight all safe.
Entry.213:
Painting wagons.

Lovely moonlight the last few nights and Fritz has taken full advantage of it, for dropping bombs. He has missed our camp so far but we get a lot of shrapnel from the anti-aircraft guns, one piece struck our tent but did not go through.
Entry.214:
Painting boxes for the Captain.

On sick lines on Piquet. First shift 6 till 10pm.

Fritz droped great number of bombs between 7 and 9pm the nearest about 200 yrds.
Entry.215: Painting a cross for no.549 R. Freyer T.M.B who was killed on the
Entry.217:
Nr Reninghelst

Painting cross

8pm Fritz having another go with his bombs
Entry.219:
Nr Reninghelst

Raining very heavy.

2.30am pulled out of bed and had to harness up read to move out by 3.30am (4 teams going out) Arr.Berna Hill Dump (on outside of Ypres) about 5.30am Carting empty ammunition boxes from there to Howe Dump. Done three trips arrived back in lines about 3pm.Fritz sending over liquid fire shells about a mile to the right of us.

Thursday 4th October 1917

Painting very heavy rain during the night. Met L. Mills of Malvern who is in 2nd D. at C.
Entry.220:
Nr Reninghelst

Harnessed up and left lines at 2pm. going to Krustraat Dump for ammunition. About 2 miles from the lines, motor wagons bumped into my donk giving him a nast cut so had to unhook my two donks and return to lines. Had wound dressed by Vet. Serg. Of 2nd Battery
Entry.222:
Finished painting Cross for R.Freyer (no549) and Gunner E. Wilson (no14 x2A T.M.B.

Both killed in action on
Entry.223:
Sunday 7th October

Harnessed up and left lines with wagon at 8am. Were to cart bricks from the old gun pits to the new but on account of the rain the track was so mudy that it was impossible to get to the pits. Donks up to the belly in mud in some places about 2 miles from Hell fire corner (on the way to the pits) our wagon got bogged. After struggling with it for nearly two hours we had to leave it. Got soaked to the skin and glad when we got back to the lines and got some dry clothes on. Arr back about 3pm
Entry.224:
Nr Reninghelst

Left lines with team about 7.30am going up the line to try and get our waggon out. Got to within a mile of the wagon when our Donks got bogged. Great job in getting them out, could not get along the track with the Donks so useless to try and bring a wagon so we were told to return to the lines. Arr back in lines a 2.30pm. Started raining very heavy about 5pm.
Entry.225:
Painting tucker boxes (2) for Officers Mess.

Mounted stable Piquet at 6pm on second shift 10pm till2am

Fritz dropping bombs about 4am
Entry.226:
Reninghelst

Harnessed up and left lines t 8.30am. Went to 5th Bdge.H.Q. for Officers and mens kits and brought them back to lines near Reninghelst.

Arrived back in the lines about 6pm. While getting our load at H.Q. Fritz shelling very heavy to the right of Hell Fire corner. 

Hell fire corner is a place that makes the religious minded say their prayers, the fatalist repose himself upon one or other of his pet quotations, or the gambler bet that the odds against himself and comrades passing it safely were a hundred to one.

Briefly Hell Fire corner is one of these places that look so very innocent at one moment and then the next without any warning prove a little h…
Entry.227:
Got paid this morning 55 francs

Painting tucker boxes (2) for Officers Mess.
Entry.230: Grooming and cleaning lines. Half holiday
Entry.231:
Reninghelst

Grooming and harness cleaning.

Fritz over our lines about 8pm dropping bombs. The search light got on the first one then the guns opened out on him. They got that close to him that he dropped his load quick and lively and made back to his own lines. Lovely sight seeing about 15 or 20 search light sweeping the sky.
Entry.234:
Left lines at 7am with wagon.

Went to 104th Batt. Wagon lines (nr Ypres). Carting bricks from Ypres to 104th horse lines. Got stuck one or twice in shell holes, finished about 4pm and arrived back in our lines about 5.30pm
Entry.235:
Reninghelst

Grooming and harness cleaning.

Mounted guard at 5pm.
Entry.236:
Grooming and harness cleaning.

4pm warned to leave for Boulogne at 7am tomorrow morning for remounts. Taking saddle, two bridles and ets.
Entry.237:
7am Put our kits in wagon and left lines about 8am. Marched to Poperinge where we left by train at 9.45am

Passed through Godewadersvelde,Hazebrock,Ebbinghume,St Omer,Calais, arriving Boulogne at 6.20pm

Cont.

Carried our kits form the station to our billets (10 minute walk) at Rue d Arret. Had tea then spent the rest of the evening in the city. As the city is darkness I spent the most of my time in a café eating fish, eggs, chips etc.
Entry.238:
Boulogne

Rev. 6am 8am put kits in motor 9am moved out of billet and marched to remount depot which was about 8 miles from Boulogne. After walking about 4 miles the motor wagon that took our saddles and kits met us so we got a lift to the depot.

 After waiting there we saddled up (I had two light draft horses) and left about 1pm. (Horses and mules for D.A.C. Engineers and details about 200 all told).

Our first stop (9 miles) Disvres where we arrived about 3.30pm ffed up 5.30 billets I cement works dismissed till next morning.
Entry.239:
Disvres.

Rev 6am fed up 6.30am and moved off 9.30am

Our next stopping place is to be Therouanne which is 21 miles from Disvres

About 5.30pm.

Fed horses then dismissed had good huts to sleep in close to stable. John and I went into village which was full of Portuguese.
Entry.240:
Therouanne

Rev. 6am moved off at 9am our next stop to be Hazebrock 18 miles from Therouanne. Passed through Rebecq, Roquetorie, Blaringhum,Sercus, arriving Hazebrock about 4pm fed up at 5.30pm.Detailed for piquet which I mounted at 6pm filled hay nets and as my shift was from 12 till 1am I went into Hazebrock for the evening which was about 2 kilos away. Very heavy rain all night.
Entry.241:
Hazebroch

Rev. at 6am did not move of till near 10am. One of the infantry boys got his legs broken by one of the mules kicking him. Have to finish trip today, 21 miles to do. Passed through Caestre, Godewodersvelde, Boeschepe, Reninghelst, Ouderdum, arriving at our destination, Belgium Chateau (outskirts of Yeaps) about 4.30pm.Took our saddles and ets off horses waited about 1½ hours put saddles on a ;mule and rode home to our lines arr.in lines about 7pm.
Entry.242:
Reninghelst

Raining very heavy, so cleaning harness in humpy.
Entry.244: 4.30am Fed my two mules. Breakfast, harnessed up and moved out with wagon at 6am. One load of duck boards from R.E.Dump to Dickebusch to 4th bde. H.L ne Howe dump arr home 9pm.
Entry.245:
Nr Reninghelst

8am left lines with wagons.

Took one load of smoke shells from Howe Dump to forward dump (passed Hell Fire corner)

Arrived back in lines about 1pm.
Entry.246:
Grooming and harness cleaning.

Fritz very lively with his bombs during the night.
Entry.251: Grooming got leave and spent the afternoon in Poperinge. Ted Aulesbrook returned to camp.
Entry.253:
7.30 am left lines and reported to 10th Bat. Lines (near Ypres) with wagon. Got a guide to take us to the pits. We had to go about 31/2 miles along the corduroy road. Fritz shell very heavy (all big stuff). Dead horses and mules, wagons and limbers lying on both sides of the road. Very wild looking place, and I was glad when we got out of it. Every pillbox we passed was blown to pieces.

While getting our load of empty shell cases he (Fritz) was trying to get on a heavy battery with his coal boxes. As we were only about 100 yrds away we wasted no time in loading up. Arr home safe at 5.30.
Entry.256:
Grooming and harness cleaning.

Mounted sick line Piquet at 5pm on second shift 7.20pm to 9.40pm and 2 till 4am
Entry.257:
Café Hendrick

Painting notice board for drying room. 7.30pm ordered to harness up by 8pm, take ets and 24 hour rations. Kept waiting for over 1 hour at 2nd station. No idea where we are going to. Very wild night,12.30pm arr café Hendrick (between Dickebusch and Ypres). Had good billet to sleep in.
Entry.258: Piquet fed mules so did not get out of bed till near 9am. Done nothing all day except attend to mules. Kennedy, Smallwood and I had small room to ourselves.
Entry.259:
Café Hendrick between Dickebusch and Ypres.

Put in charge of feed while staying at this place
Entry.260:
Filled the nose bags (60) in the morning and afternoon.

7.30 pm ordered to harness up and return to our waggon lines. Very foggy going home. At times I could hardly see my donks head. Arrived back to lines without any mishap about 10pm. Sorry to come back, as we were having a good time.
Entry.261:
Bussiboom nr Reninghelst

Grooming and harness cleaning.
Entry.262:
Harnessed up and moved out of lines by 7.30am. Carting bricks from Ypres to Dickebusch Rd. for the winter horse lines.

14 Fritz’s planes over Ypres 3 Yothas.

Arrived back in lines about 3pm.
Entry.263:
Bussiboom nr Reninghelst

8.30 left lines with wagon. Carting bricks from Ypres to winter stables.

Coming home motor wagon run into the Donk that I was riding, giving the donk a very nasty leg.
Entry.266:
Bussiboom

8.30am Harnessed up and left lines to cart bricks from Ypres to winter stables.

Arrived back to lines about 3pm.
Entry.267:
Grooming and harness cleaning till11am. Saddled up a mule, and sent to a railway siding about six miles away for remounts. When we got to the siding, the train had not arrived so we had to wait about an hour. Brought two horses home. Arr. back in lines at 5.30

Mounted stable piquet 2nd shift at 7.20 to 9.40pm and 2 till 4am.
Entry.268:
Bussiboom

Harnessed and left lines at noon. Went to Taylor dump for Lieut. Hearn’s and men’s kits. Arrived back to lines at 5pm.

Packed my kit as we are shifting our camp tomorrow morning.
Entry.269:
Stweenwerck

All teams harnessed up and ready to move out at 9am.

9.30 pulled out from camp with four mule team. Arrived at our destination Pont d’achelles near Steenwerch about 1pm. Good stables and good huts to sleep.
Entry.271:
Grooming and harness cleaning.

Half holiday
Entry.272:
Grooming and harness cleaning half holiday

Had leave into Steenwerck where I met K. Mitchell.
Entry.274: Gunners and drivers sent to different batteries.9am Saddled up mule and led another to 4th Bde. Got back to camp about 1pm
Entry.275:
Grooming and harness cleaning.

Half holiday
Entry.276:
Exercising mules from 9am till 11am

harness cleaning in afternoon
Entry.277:
Nr Steenwerck

Exercising mules from 9am till about 11pm. Harness cleaning in the afternoon
Entry.278:
Grooming and harness cleaning.

Half holiday
Entry.279: 9am harnessed ;up four mule team. Took gunners and drivers kits to 5th Bde. Got back to camp about 4pm
Entry.280:
Nr Steenwerck

Went to dentist near Steenwerck.

Got back to camp about noon. Harness cleaning in the afternoon.
Entry.281: Exercising mules in the morning. Harness cleaning in the afternoon.
Entry.282:
Nr Steenwerck

Dentist in the morning.Half holiday 12 till4pm

"B" Echelon beat the 9th Fld. Amb. At football 2 to 1

Orderly room burnt.4 or 5 Fritz balloons over our lines dropping bills
Entry.284:
Nr Steenwerck

Grooming and harness cleaning.
Entry.285:
Grooming and harness cleaning.

Half holiday
Entry.286: Holiday only fed and watered mules
Entry.287:
Steenwerck

Grooming and harness cleaning

Painting numbers on wagons in the afternoon
Entry.288:
Grooming and harness cleaning

Painting numbers on wagons in the afternoon
Entry.289:
Steenwerck

Harnessed up and left lines by 11am. 10.30 inspection by General Smyth. Went to dump for load of coal and timber for cooks.

Got back to lines by 12noon. Half holiday. Our section beat the 3rd D.A.C. at football 61 to 28.

Fritz dropping bombs
Entry.291:
Steenwerck

Painting numbers on waggons

Mounted stable piquet at 5pm 

sick lines.

On first shift 5 till 7.20pm and 12 till 2am
Entry.292:
Painting numbers on wagons. Half holiday.

Received pocket writing pad from Y.M.C.A.

Half holiday 12 till 3.30pm 1st section beat "B" Echelon at football (Australian rules) by one point.
Entry.294:
Pont d’Achelles

Grooming and harness cleaning
Entry.295:
Near Steenwerch

Grooming and harness cleaning
Entry.296:
Pont d’Achelles

Grooming and harness cleaning, half holiday
Entry.297:
Near Steenwerch

Grooming and harness cleaning
Entry.298:
Pont d’achelles

Grooming and harness cleaning
Entry.299:
Near Steenwerch

Grooming and harness cleaning half holiday
Entry.300: Carting small arms ammunition from railway siding to our lines. Got home about 2pm.
Entry.301:
Pont d’achelles

Grooming and harness cleaning
Entry.302:
Pont d’achelles

Holiday 

 Received parcel from Melb. Mayoress comfort fund. 

Had A1 dinner.
Entry.303:
Pont d’achelles

Grooming and harness cleaning
Entry.304:
Grooming and harness cleaning.

Xmas concert
